title: Jama Ali Korshel
text:
Jama Ali Korshel (, ) was a <a href="Somali%20people">Somali</a> <a href="Military%20of%20Somalia">army</a> <a href="General%20officer">Major General</a> and former Head of the <a href="Somali%20Police%20Force">Somali Police Force</a>. He was the <a href="Vice%20President%20of%20Somalia">Vice President</a> of the <a href="Supreme%20Revolutionary%20Council%20%28Somalia%29">Supreme Revolutionary Council</a>.
Biography.
Korshel was born in the town of <a href="Erigavo">Erigavo</a>, situated in the eastern <a href="Sanaag">Sanaag</a> region of Somaliland. Korshel completed the Quran in Erigavo and started school at <a href="SOS%20Sheikh%20Secondary%20School">SOS Sheikh Secondary School</a> to finish his middle school education. The SOS Sheikh Secondary School is situated near the town of Sheikh in a remote part of present day <a href="Somaliland">Somaliland</a>. Korshel finished his high school studies in Aden, Yemen. After completing high school Korshel went back to northern Somalia and joined the police force. He was given a scholarship to go to the National Police College in Ryton-on-Dunsmore, Warwickshire, England to complete his training. 
He was a leader in the <a href="Somali%20National%20League">Somali National League</a> (SNL) when <a href="British%20Somaliland">British Somaliland</a> gained its independence in 1960. Following the establishment of the <a href="Somali%20Republic">Somali Republic</a> and the assassination of the young nation's second president, <a href="Abdirashid%20Ali%20Sharmarke">Abdirashid Ali Sharmarke</a>, Korshel would later emerge as one of the key figures in the <a href="1969%20Somali%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">1969 Somali coup d'état</a> which saw the <a href="military%20junta">military junta</a> of <a href="Major%20General">Major General</a> <a href="Mohamed%20Siad%20Barre">Mohamed Siad Barre</a> take power. He was appointed Vice President of the new <a href="Supreme%20Revolutionary%20Council%20%28Somalia%29">Supreme Revolutionary Council</a> (SRC) that assumed office, and put in charge of Internal Affairs.
In 1970, an alleged <a href="Coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">counter-coup d'état</a> attempt, reportedly masterminded by Korshel, was uncovered. Korshel was subsequently arrested in April 1971, until 1975, when he was released from prison. Korshel later embarked on a business career.
He died in 1989 in <a href="London">London</a>, <a href="England">England</a>, and was subsequently flown to <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a>, where a religious ceremony was held in his honor before finally being laid to rest in <a href="Mogadishu">Mogadishu</a>.
Korshel's son, <a href="Said%20Jama%20Mohamed">Said Korshel</a>, would later follow in his father's footsteps, entering politics and serving in the <a href="Puntland">Puntland</a> regional administration as a minister between 2002-2007 and the federal Government of Somalia as Minister of Transportation.
